line_1: For when they praise your blinking ee,
line_2: 'Tis certain that your gowd they see:

line_1: But now when it streykes there's a tear i' my ee.
line_2: Of aw hours it telt eight was dearest to me,

line_1: An' ilk ane strives to catch his ee,
line_2: At last he cums, and on his knee

line_1: But the sly dad aft blinks his ee,
line_2: "Cum, Bess, fling by the wheel," says he,

line_1: Though often I danc'd wi' the tear i' my ee.
line_2: To sing or to dance was nae pleasure to me,

line_1: Wi' saut tears i' my ee;
line_2: To sic a thing as ye.

line_1: Things a' look dull i' the watery ee
line_2: Her saffron robe is nought to me,

line_1: A' things look beauteous i' the ee
line_2: Her hamely garb was mair to me
When I take leave o' thee?

line_1: And keep friends i' the ee;
line_2: What can part thee and me!
